narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The study aims to investigate anxiety symptoms and resilience processes in adolescents using longitudinal behavioral, clinical, and neurobiological assessments. The types of scientific data expected to be generated include demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures (e.g., heart rate variability), derived summary variables, and documentation (protocols, data dictionary, README). Given the longitudinal nature of the study and the collection of multi-modal data across multiple time points, a substantial amount of data is expected to be generated. The largest portion of storage will be dedicated to physiological data and raw task files.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data collected from this project, including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral task data, physiological measures, and derived summary variables, will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and advancement of research in adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms. By making these data available, other researchers can build upon our findings, explore new hypotheses, and contribute to the development of more effective interventions.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments, data dictionaries that define each variable, README files explaining the content and structure of the datasets, and detailed information about the methods used for data collection and analysis. These resources will provide context and ensure that the shared data can be understood and utilized effectively by other researchers.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate some of the shared scientific data, particularly for analyzing physiological measures and behavioral task data. The specific tools include:
Statistical analysis software (e.g., R, Python libraries such as Pandas and NumPy) for data manipulation and analysis.
Specialized software for processing and analyzing physiological data (e.g., EDFbrowser for EEG data).
Behavioral task data may require custom scripts or software provided by the task developers.

These tools and software can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories. For custom code developed during this project, it will be shared via a public repository (e.g., GitHub), ensuring transparency and facilitating collaboration.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. Specifically:
Demographic and clinical datasets will adhere to standardized formats used in psychiatric research (e.g., DSM-5 codes for diagnoses).
Physiological measures will follow standards established by relevant professional societies (e.g., guidelines from the Society for Psychophysiological Research for EEG data).
Behavioral task data will be formatted according to standards set by the task developers or, where applicable, broader standards in cognitive neuroscience research.
Metadata will include detailed descriptions of methods and instruments used, consistent with recommendations from the NIH for metadata standards.

Applying these standards ensures that our datasets can be easily integrated with existing resources, promoting collaborative research and meta-analyses.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive (NDA), a repository that aligns with NIH's data sharing policies and provides a secure platform for storing and sharing human subjects data. The NDA is specifically designed to facilitate data sharing in mental health research, making it an ideal choice for our study.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure the scientific data are findable and identifiable, each dataset will be assigned a unique identifier (e.g., DOI) upon deposition into the NDA. Additionally, detailed metadata describing each dataset, including information about the study design, population, methods, and variables measured, will be provided. This metadata will be searchable through the NDA's query tool, allowing other researchers to easily locate and access our datasets.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings or at the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Data will be available for a minimum of 10 years following the end of the project to allow for extended research use and integration with future studies.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer:
While maximizing data sharing is a priority, certain factors may limit the extent of data sharing. These include:
Informed consent limitations: Participants provided broad consent for de-identified data sharing, but any identifiable information will be protected.
Privacy and confidentiality protections: All shared data will be de-identified to protect participant privacy.
Potential risks to participants if data are not properly de-identified.

These factors are justifiable reasons for limiting certain aspects of data sharing and have been considered in the development of this Data Management and Sharing Plan.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NDA's access request system. Researchers requesting access will need to provide a brief description of their intended use of the data, agree to terms of use that include protecting participant confidentiality, and may require approval from our research team or an NDA-appointed data access committee.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be thoroughly de-identified. This process includes removing direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses), indirect identifiers (e.g., dates of birth, zip codes), and applying statistical methods to prevent re-identification. Additionally, a Certificate of Confidentiality has been obtained to further safeguard against compelled disclosure of identifying information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the research team's data manager and institutional officials responsible for research integrity and compliance. Regular oversight meetings will occur quarterly to review data management practices, ensure adherence to sharing timelines, and address any issues or concerns related to data privacy and access. The PI will also work closely with the NDA to ensure that all deposited data meet their standards for sharing and accessibility. Through this structured approach, we aim to maintain high standards of data stewardship and contribute meaningfully to the broader research community.
